title: Will the Democratic Republic of the Congo hold presidential elections in 2016?
possible_answers: Yes, and Joseph Kabila Kabange will win
Yes, and Moise Katumbi Chapwe will win
Yes, but neither Kabila nor Katumbi will win

The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) says it will push back next month's presidential election to April 2018, in a move that is expected to keep President Joseph Kabila in office until the delayed vote. http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/10/drc-delays-election-2018-opposition-anger-161016135155845.html

According to the news the delay of elections favors the actual president of DRC. There is no interest from his side to hold elections this year, because he wants to stay in power.The opposition wants Kabila to end his 15-year rule in December as mandated by the constitution but authorities say the vote cannot be held until at least next July, and the top court has said Kabila can stay in power until the election is held. (http://www.aljazeera.com/amp/news/2016/08/dr-congo-opposition-rejects-talks-election-160821050327293.html). The registration of voters takes time too and is a logistical issue that obstruct elections this year and probably next year.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Elections scheduled for December 2018.  The Congo has not had a peaceful transfer of power since independence in 1960.  With help, two years seems to be enough time to do this right.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-congo-politics-idUSKCN1241SB?il=0

Kabila's term ends on 20 Dec, and elections were originally supposed to be held on 27 Nov.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo_general_election,_2018 The Election Commission has said it can't hold elections till 2018. Although there have been protests against this, and the resulting likelihood of Kabila remaining in office beyond expiry of his term, there seems just too little time remaining for elections to be held this year.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

There is outrage and protest but it seems done and dusted.

The government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has rejected fresh demands from the opposition that elections be held and President Joseph Kabila step down by December 20 of this year. http://www.voanews.com/content/drc-government-rejects-opposition-demand-for-election-by-year-end/3443756.html

Political tensions are high in Congo before a scheduled November presidential election. President Joseph Kabila, in power since 2001, is required by the constitution to step down this year but the government says logistical and budgetary constraints make it unrealistic to hold the election on time. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-congo-rights-idUSKCN1012IE Obvious BS, yet no world leaders are calling for sanctions, boycotts or any other action to address this obvious lie.

The year is marching on and there is little sign of movement on this. 
Even less likely to happen.

@Intriligator:  @Intrilligator: Constitutional court 11 May ruled that President Kabila could legally stay in office after his second term ends in Dec if elections have not been held. Main opposition parties rejected judgement, called for protest marches. Anti-govt protests held throughout country 26 May, clashed with police in several cities, one protester and one policeman killed in Goma. Ex-Katanga Governor Moïse Katumbi 4 May said he would run in presidential elections; govt same day opened investigation into Katumbi’s alleged hiring of foreign mercenaries in plot against govt. Prosecutor general 19 May issued arrest warrant for him but Katumbi flew with prosecutor’s permission to South Africa 20 May for medical treatment, 27 May flew to Europe. Attacks on civilians rose in eastern Beni territory, North Kivu, attributed to Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) rebels, leaving at least twenty people dead; armed forces 14 May launched new operation against ADF. Political manoeuvring over electoral crisis continued as ethnic tensions rose in east. Ruling party Sec Gen 4 June raised possibility of referendum on constitution to extend President Kabila’s rule. Etienne Tshisekedi, leader of opposition Union of Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS), brought together representatives of most opposition parties and civil society near Brussels 8-9 June: participants rejected dialogue as foreseen by Kabila but called for UN, EU, AU, International Organisation of La Francophonie and U.S. to support AU-appointed facilitator Edem Kodjo, established “Rassemblement” follow-up mechanism. Tshisekedi met Kodjo in Brussels 17 June, expressed support for dialogue in spirit of UNSC Resolution 2277. In east, army and UN operations against Rwandan Hutu rebel group Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR) stoked tensions between Hutu and other ethnic groups at Buleusa, eastern Walikale; non-Hutu groups suspected Hutu of complicity with FDLR. UN Force Intervention Brigade 16 June reportedly killed seven Mai Mai militants who tried to block food distribution to displaced people in Buleusa camp. U.S. imposed sanctions on Kinshasa police chief Céléstin Kanyama 23 June for “violence against civilians”.

«DR Congo risks 'even worse crisis' over Kabila uncertainty:
...
'Tensions rose further when the country's Constitutional Court ruled in May [1] that Kabila could remain in a caretaker capacity beyond December until elections are held.
The strongman's supporters want elections, due later this year, to be delayed for two to four years. No date has yet been set for the polls.
Last month, opposition parties forged an alliance to demand Kabila quit his post in December, warning that him staying on would be tantamount to a "constitutional coup d'etat".  » [2]
[1] «Following the principle of continuity for the state and to avoid a lack of head of state, the current president remains in office until the installation of a newly-elected president," said the Constitutional Court statement read by its head, Benoit Luamba Bintu. The court was responding to a request to clarify the matter.»

No:        87 - 2 from 89%
YaJKK:   7   +2 from 5 The electoral process is on his way. Joseph Kabila Kabange ask congolese a good participation in the census. He remind that Congo is a democracy and he doesn't want blood [1]. A poll (on line) organized by Radiookapi asked readers if partial revision of the electoral list should be held, and then respect the constitution of Congo. 
54% answered "it's a good idea"; 
34% this idea will not be adopted and 
11% "this is not a good idea" 2451 response. [2] This poll, as i see, it tell me:
1- The person who propose this idea (président of the political party "Mon beau pays") have serious doubt about the tenure of the election because of the census;
2- This idea, to have a partial revision of the electoral list, is  good. Probably because it provides better possibilities for an election in the constitutional time frame. Overall, i wouldn't be surprise if a constitutional reform is on the way. Maybe, by the way, a proposition to allow Kabange  others candidacy.  [1] «Nous sommes en démocratie et nous devons organiser des élections dans tout  le pays. Donc, il faut se préparer pour le processus électoral, qui démarre en juillet jusqu’à l’organisation des élections», a fait savoir Joseph Kabila.
Le chef de l’Etat a fait savoir que les élections ne vont pas s'accompagner d’effusion du sang.  
« Pour la démocratie, nous allons organiser les élections dans ce pays. Tous ceux qui disent qu’il n’y aura pas d’élection et déclarent que le sang va couler, alors s’ils viennent ici [Kalemie], il faut leur demander: le sang de qui va couler ? Parce qu’à Kalemie, on a versé beaucoup de sang et nous ne voulons plus que le sang coule », a-t-il indiqué.» [1]

Now this is interesting: http://www.africanews.com/2016/06/20/drc-gov-t-directs-internet-service-providers-to-restore-tariffs/
Rather than shutting down the Internet, as happened last year, the government has decided to simply price it out of the reach of most citizens. This follows recent (unconfirmed) reports that more than 100 higher education institutions have been closed since late last year. 
If you wanted to minimize the chances of an uprising over, say, postponed elections, this would be a pretty good way to do it.

If Kabila continues to insist on the electorial reforms AND the census that would be needed for them, there is just no way to get this done in time. In fact, this make take several more months and may easily derail into 1-2 years. The only reason why I am not at 99% at NO is that he might not care too much over the quality of the census. Then again: This is probably nothing more than a stalling tactic and he might use the objective difficulties in conducting a census as such. As long as there is no legal way for him to take office for a third term, he will want to sit this out. I am unsure if he can amend the consitution in time and he doesn't seem too eager to get this done in time anyway. Maybe he is speculating that at some point the majority will be fine with an amendment of the constitution as long as they get any elections?

There is no requirement, either in this Q or in the real world, that these elections must comply with either the legal norms of the DRC or the standards of common decency.   The Kabila family are not noted for their commitment to legal processes or even, as above, common decency.  If I'm Joe, I brush aside the niggling domestic, constitutional, and international objections and open the polls, at the same time asking people to lift that pesky term limit.  I win, to the surprise of let's say nobody.   This prediction subject to change without notice.  Consult dealer for details.

@cdob63 :  Current updates and string evidentiary information that the election will not be held due to stated reasons. Before voting can happen, both the government and opposition agree that voter rolls must be updated. But there is disagreement over the timeline for these updates. According to a chart prepared by the country’s electoral commission (CENI) on January 10, 2016, and posted by the president of the UK-based Association for Development and Democracy in Congo, this process would lead to a delay of at least 13 months. On the other hand, according to the UK’s Special Envoy to Africa’s Great Lakes Region, it would be technically possible to hold the elections in November 2016, even with an update of the voter rolls. Opposition leader Katumbi agrees with the UK assessment and thinks that with help from the UN this process should take a maximum of six months. Pressure is growing on Kabila not to postpone elections and to allow the
first democratic transition of power in the country since independence. If the last few months of delaying tactics are any indication, however, even if Kabila decides not to run, elections are unlikely to take place on time in November 2016.

The 27th November 2016 elections have been scheduled and confirmed.  However given the volatility and instability in the DRC and the pivotal issue of a third term for the incumbent, will most likely lead to repression of opposition, dissidents, and civilians who oppose the third term push as unconstitutional.

These things are usually long drawn out affairs. 
Unlikely to happen this year.
Adjusting forecasts to match consensus. My priors haven't update though.

Everything indicates another African dictator will refuse to go into the Good Night and hold on to power with the determination of an iron toothed limpet. Consensus is 88%, I feel confident not this year.

how many times have we seen this story? The elections almost never proceed. If they do, it will be in 2017. Between arresting his opponent, amending the constitution and military crackdowns, even if there are sanctions it will likely only result in an announcement of elections, but not actual elections in 2016. The sham governors elections give him more of a hold on resources and localities, enough so that he can hold them "hostage." It is difficult to see a) he will go without a fight and b) that will happen in 2016.  I am giving little credence to the first option, since there are term limits, and rather that have an election where he is term limited out, it is far easier and cleaner just to refuse to give power up, or to amend the constitution.

When the incumbent seeks to modify the constitution to seek an extra term, that's never a sign that elections will proceed as planned. The violence that has plagued Burundi has been caused in large part due to that country's president seeking a third term. Either way, this suggest Kabange will use extra legal means to attempt to ensure his hold on power. So, either there will not be elections (likely), or the elections will be held, but in a way to ensure Kabange will win.

Figaro reports on 21 May that Moise is being threatened with jail. The photo of  him in article wearing slick Pierre Balmain sports jacket doesn't win him many votes from economically disadvantaged folks though.

Trying: the Democratic Republic of Congo The “democratic” label will be severely tested today. For the third time this week Moise Katumbi, a populist politician, returns to court in Lubumbashi, the second city, to face accusations of hiring mercenaries—charges most people think are trumped-up. Mr Katumbi, a former governor of the mineral-rich province of Katanga as well as the owner of TP Mazembe, one of Africa's most successful football teams, announced last week he intends to run for the presidency. Elections are due in November, but Joseph Kabila, the incumbent, seems unwilling to organise them, or to step down when his term ends. Mr Katumbi was once a close ally of Mr Kabila; he now seems the president’s biggest threat. He went to court on Monday and Wednesday followed by a jubilant crowd that the police were forced to disperse with tear gas. The charges may do nothing to scupper his ambitions. [From The Economist Espresso]
****
The Democratic Republic of Congo’s government issued a warrant for the arrest of presidential hopeful Moise Katumbi on charges that he recruited mercenaries.
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-19/congo-issues-arrest-warrant-for-presidential-hopeful-katumbi
+++++++
COMMENT:
Political tensions have risen throughout the Democratic Republic of Congo, as political and religious leaders, activists, students, and others have spoken out against proposed changes to Congo’s constitution and other proposals that would allow President Joseph Kabila to stay in power for longer than the two consecutive terms currently permitted. Government authorities have sought to silence dissent with threats, violence, and arbitrary arrests. In eastern Congo, dozens of armed groups remain active. Many of their commanders lead forces that have been responsible for numerous war crimes for which few have been held accountable. Congolese army soldiers have also been responsible for abuses against the civilian population they are meant to protect.
**Nothing of all this is new in some regions of Africa. I doubt Kabila will juts give up, and if rebels will oust Kabila, elections won't be hold very soon.

From Bloomberg this morning: "The Democratic Republic of Congo’s government issued a warrant for the arrest of presidential hopeful Moise Katumbi on charges that he recruited mercenaries." http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-19/congo-issues-arrest-warrant-for-presidential-hopeful-katumbi I read this as strong confirmation of the view that Kabila & co. are looking to continue stalling, and to shut down rivals who prepare to challenge them. So I'm tilting harder toward a forecast that sees an election as very unlikely (90%) and expects that, if one is held, it will be because Kabila has shut down his opponents and is confident he can win (8/1/1). The dark horse here is the possibility of a sustained rebellion that ousts Kabila and leads to elections in which he's not even running. I see that as very unlikely, however, and I am guessing that if it does happen, it won't get all the way to elections before the end of 2016.

Katumbi charged with hiring foreign mercenaries.  Expected to be either jailed or placed under house arrest.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36336697 Katumbi leaves for South Africa (for medical treatment). Kabila says Katumbi is welcome back at any time.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-congodemocratic-rights-idUSKCN0YB2C4?il=0 Coincidences are starting to add up:
1. Katumbi announces run for President immediatly after investigation is announced.
2. Leaves for SAf medical treatment immediately after charges are filed and arrest warrent issued.

Not a good record in the region for the likelihood of an election being held as promised. Can't see Kabila willingly putting his presidency on the line unless he felt confident of victory. Bloody times ahead?

Congo's constitutional court said Wednesday the president can stay in office beyond his mandate if there is a delay in presidential elections, slated for November. President Joseph Kabila, who has been in power since 2001 and is meant to leave office in December, is barred by the constitution from seeking a third term. The opposition has voiced concerns for some time that Kabila would delay elections to stay in power.
http://www.france24.com/en/20160512-drcongo-court-joseph-kabila-mandate-presidential-elections
=========
That says it!

The May 11th decision by top Congo court indicates that if the election is not held on time, Kabila will remain in power.  Given the lack of voter registries, etc., the odds that the elections are held on time decrease, since Kabila will have no incentive to rush the process.
http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/drc-top-court-says-president-joseph-kabila-can-stay-leader-after-glissement-ruling-1559446  US decision to possibly apply sanctions, if Kabila does not leave office at end of term, seems to imply an over ride of Congo's court system.

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/world/africa/congo-moise-katumbi-joseph-kabila.html?emc=edit_th_20160512&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=70183565&_r=0
Congo’s government is clearly stressed. Global commodity prices have crashed, pummeling a country whose struggling economy turns on the price of minerals like copper. China, which had been Congo’s new savior, has its own economic woes and is in no position to extend the billions of dollars of easy credit it had in the past. On top of that, Western governments are considering sanctions against Congolese officials for human rights abuses in connection with the political crackdowns. Lambert Mende, the information minister and a close ally of Mr. Kabila’s, said in a recent interview that the government did not have enough money to hold elections. He also said that if the president agreed to step down at the end of the year but the election was then delayed, “we’d start confusion, we’d start rebellions, we’d start wars.”

Some news: Top DR Congo court says Kabila can remain president if elections delayed: http://www.france24.com/en/20160512-drcongo-court-joseph-kabila-mandate-presidential-elections US to enforce DRC sanctions if President Kabila does not hold democratic elections
http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/us-enforce-drc-sanctions-if-president-kabila-does-not-hold-democratic-elections-1559507

Great overview of the current situation from Kris Berwouts in African Arguments: http://africanarguments.org/2016/05/11/moise-katumbi-and-the-congos-race-for-the-presidency/ I read this as largely consistent with my priors -- election unlikely, but Katumbi a modest favorite if one happens, because it would mean Kabila had been wrong-footed in the first place -- so I am leaving my forecasts unchanged.
Typical man in power won't give it up. If he can get military support then he stays if not things get messy.

"Politicians and diplomats privately admit polls in 2016 are an impossibility and the Kabila government appears to favour a lag of several years."
From: http://qz.com/677456/a-soccer-loving-millionaire-wants-to-president-in-dr-congo-but-so-fast/ Katumbi announced bid for Presidency on 5/4/16.  Katumbi is the ex govornor of Katanga province (2007-2015).  Katumbi made millions in Katanga (recently split into four) reportedly sub-contracting to to the mining industry in Katanga, and ownes a popular soccer team. In 2015, joined the opposition G7 group which split from Kabila's ruling party. The group advocates "free, fair, open elections", the objective seems to be to replace Kabila. The DRc's Justice Minister has reportedly issued an arrest warrant and launched an investigation into  Katumbi's alleged use of mercenaries to recruit Congolese youth into a militia.  A second report indicates Katumbi hired an American security company to provide security advisors (unarmed, although some have military backgrounds). As western interests start to focus on Africa, regime change efforts may become more frequent.  Katumbi seems to fit the profile of a business oriented leader needed to open African economies.  The article points out that, in the event of an election, the opposition would need to consolidate in order to win a single round election.

In recent decades it has been felt necessary by incumbent autocrats to have elections, preferably featuring either rigging or grievous bodily harm.  Kabila knows this and will likely have some sort of elections, the results of which will be widely and correctly disbelieved.  Stay tuned.

After doing a little more reading, including the piece at the link below, I am betting heavily on the election not happening in 2016. If it does happen this year, though, I expect it will be under conditions that are less favorable to Kabila (which is a big part of why they are likely being delayed in the first place), so I see Katumbi as the favorite in that scenario. http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/d1fa921a-12c8-11e6-bb40-c30e3bfcf63b.html

Kabila should win re-election if the 3rd term becomes possible, or create delayed elections - if 3rd term is not possible.  G7 seems to be a regional party from the copper mining areas, and as yet, do not have widespread support.  US interested in creating limited term democracies as Africa, with it's resources, and young population, could, in future decades, become the next economic growth engine. Kabila has several options that he is pursuing: 1) a possible change in the restriction on a 3rd term (40 dead on first attempt), 2) delays in the election for new voter rolls (constitution court will be asked to rule on Art. 70 in the case of a delay "remain in office until the installation of a new President" or Art. 75 "transfer title to head of state if the office (President) is vacant.
